title: Candido - Thousand Finger Man (1970)@flac
description:
On this album, with arrangements by Joe Cain, Candido shows that there is a direct relationship between the rhythms young people are dancing to today and the rhythms originated hundreds of years ago by his ancestors.
In many definitions of soul, writers have tried to analyze the illusive element that makes one performer more exciting than another. The strength, sensitivity and excitement which characterize Candido's solos, indicate that his soul is equally divided between North and South American influences and reflects the best of both. 
Whether he is playing three conga drums simultaneously, as he does on â€œTonyâ€™s Theme,â€ â€œSoul Limbo,â€ â€œCome On Choo-Choo Trainâ€ and â€œJump Back,â€ or bongos and conga drums simultaneously, as he does on â€œThousand Finger Man,â€ he generates a special kind of rhythmic pulse that certainly should inspire new versions of current dances. When he plays only bongos as he does on â€œHallelujah!, I'm Cornin' Home,â€ the clarity and excitement that are present in his conga playing are also very evident.
When Candido plays concerts at Lincoln Center or club engagements in Las Vegas, the audience reacts as much to the visual aspects of his playing as they do to the audible aspects. But on this record Candido proves once again that you only have to listen carefully to fully appreciate the unique excitement of the â€œThousand Finger Man.â€

                                                                                                                                            Billy Taylor (original liner notes)
                                                                                                                            
 
http://i.imgur.com/HFgl9XX.jpg

Saxophone, Flute, Piccolo Flute - Joe Grimm

Trumpet - Jimmy Sedlar, Pat Russo

Producer - Duke Pearson
Recorded By - Dave Sanders
Mastered By - Ron McMaster

Recorded at A & R Studios, New York City on September 4 (#4 & 5)and September 9 (all others), 1969.
